INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This contribution analyses the features of the concept of shrine under Italian legal doctrine and legislation, with special reference to the Concordat between Italy and the Holy See of 1929 and its revision by the Agreement of 1984. In Italian juridical doctrine and legislation a shrine is traditionally considered as a specific category of holy place. Italian ecclesiastical jurists and scholars have had a long debate on the contents and significance of the term shrine. A shrine is considered as a distinct holy place in relation to an ordinary church or worship building. This distinction is based on certain features that characterize it as a specific category of holy place, such as being a place of pilgrimage, the grant of indulgences, miracles, or relics. Article 27 of the Concordat between Italy and the Holy See of 1929, established that the Shrines (in Italian ?Santuari?) of the Holy House of Loreto, Saint ?Anthony in Padua and Saint Francis in Assisi until that time under Italian secular authority, should be ceded to the direct authority of the Holy See to which should be also granted the free administration of their properties. Already during the fascist period and before the beginning of World War Two, in a short period of time after the signature of the 1929s concordat, the Basilicas of the Holy House of Loreto and of Saint ?Anthony of Padua in accordance with the civil authorities passed under the authority of the Holy See. Oddly this process of cession from Italian civil authority to the direct authority and administration of the Holy See, had never been concluded in what concerned the Shrine of Saint Francis in Assisi and its properties. So the implementation of article 27 of the Concordat of 1929, property and administration of the Sanctuary of Saint Francis in Assisi is, since then, a pending question.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In this communication the author presents the deep impact of the new media and communication instruments in the life of indigenous peoples in South America, especially focusing on concrete cases of Brazil, Bolivia and Ecuador. Initially he presents a general overview on the discussions on the concept of indigenous peoples. In a second moment is shown the demographic distribution of indigenous population in Brazil. In a second step he deals with the juridical instruments, in universal, regional and national levels, that protects the access and use of communication instruments by indigenous peoples. This communication presents some selected cases showing focusing, on how important have been and are new communication technologies for indigenous peoples. Amazonian Indians like Mario Juruna, and the Kayapo leaders are pioneers in the use of media, for political and cultural purposes. In other areas and countries of the continent media technology had been largely used by indigenous communities as an instrument for gaining political rights and of cultural preservation. In the last few years modern, cheap, easy portable media instruments are managing to bring people from remote and forgotten areas in the middle of cultural and political scene. Initially churches and NGOs were the main promoters of the joint between traditional cultures and new modern technological tools. In the course of time governments like in Bolivia and Ecuador have started to finance the access of the called ?original communities? to these instruments. Several initiatives are being taken to ensure their right to information and broadcasting. By the use of media technology peoples that usually had no voice, have now a loud forum in national and international spheres. These social and cultural changes have repercussions on correspondent juridical instruments that recognize as an indigenous people?s right the access to new communication technologies.
